review_title: Poor management, favoritism, bullying - Toxic environment
pros: Good benefits, flexible work hours
cons:
The management (or lack thereof) at Fenway Health does not in the least bit reflect the organization's mission when it comes to supporting and acknowledging its employees. There is an obvious amount of favoritism and bullying that takes place among staff across departments. Bullies are not only repeatedly given awards, but are unfairly promoted - often to supervisory level. 

What was once an organization that truly stood "For people, not profit" has become a toxic work environment full of arrogant, immature management level staff and clinicians too busy gossiping and clamoring each other down to focus on what is most important in the mission statement.

pros: Idealized mission to serve the LGBTQAI and HIV+ communities.
cons: There is a broad-based morale problem at Fenway that is corrosive within many departments of the organization.  It is fueled by the apparent double-standards between senior management and the general staff, where bullying and harassment by "important" and "high ranking" senior leaders towards lower-ranking staff members is minimized, tolerated, and invalidated.   This organization made its name on helping marginalized communities, yet turns a deaf ear to its own employees, who have been victimized by protected, internal bullies.  A demoralizing place to work, to say the least.

pros: Impressive benefits package for a non-profit and there are some staff that are seriously dedicated to the mission of the organization. Outside of these two pros, I cannot think of anything else to add.
cons:
Leadership within AIDS Action and Fenway are deeply out-of-touch with the actual needs of the communities they aim to serve and the reputation within the community among the low-income, people of color that are most directly impacted by HIV/AIDS, substance abuse, and homelessness. While Fenway/AIDS Action has the ability (budget, manpower, real estate, etc...) to be a leader in these spaces, they will never succeed unless the entire C-suite, most VPs, and many directors are replaced with people that actually know how to build a community-based organization that actually aims to serve and represent the community of which it is supposedly based.

Outside of the issues of reputation, Fenway Health and AIDS Action have serious, serious issues with equitable compensation and employee retention. It is the norm to give front-line staff waaaaay too much work with little to no training and then sit back and watch what happens. It is important to note that a case manager within an AIDS Action program will get paid considerably less than one within a Fenway Health program.

Even worse, when staff ask for more support such as: A) on-site behavioral health staff (you know, a no-brainer for people working directly with those impacted by chronical mental illnesses), B) adequate training in responding to suicide prevention/conflict de-escalation, or C) god forbid--compensation that equals the labor you are providing to an organization that does not care, for even a second, about your well-being, you will be ignored, yes'd to death, or worse, black-listed and retaliated against.

It's quite easy to understand why these disparities exist; Fenway Health cares about their shiny, impressive health centers that are frequented by the upper-middle class, white, cis-, gay men that attend their events. They don't care about the people of color living in the neighborhoods of Boston that have been historically impacted by the insidious racism that has DIRECTLY led to the extreme disparities in life expectancy between whites and people of color in Boston. And while this racist paradigm continues,  their reputation is going to continue to falter, and they are going to continue to put their staff at risk until something truly terrible happens.
